Y8atu1GD.question: Which of the following statements is/are correct? - 1. The freezing point for Jet A is at a higher temperature than that for Jet B. - 2. The flash point for Jet A is at a higher temperature than that for Jet B.

options.text: Both 1 and 2 are correct.
Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.
1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.

QieNB1Mm.question: Which of the following is indicated in the cockpit for the fuel system?

options.text: Fuel quantity.
Tank-sensor location.
Tank pressure.
Refuelling-valve position.

HS2fhLkJ.question: On a jet aeroplane, fuel heaters are:

options.text: located on the engines.
installed in each tank.
installed only in the centre tank.
not necessary at all.

VRo90OR0.question: The purpose of baffle check valves fitted in aircraft fuel tanks is to

options.text: prevent fuel movement to the wing tip.
prevent positive pressure buildup inside the tank.
close the vent lines in case of turbulence.
damp out movement of the fuel in the tank.

jMbZkiXD.question: Fuel system indications available to the pilot are normally restricted to

options.text: fuel contents; fuel low level; fuel pressure; fuel flow; fuel transfer status; fuel filter condition.

Hh4vBTCm.question: During refuelling (pressure refuelling) of a modern passenger transport aeroplane fuel system, which component would prevent the required tank vent space being filled with fuel?

options.text: the automatic fuelling shutoff valve.
the cross-feed valve.
the jettison valve.
the diffuser.

byYx5VKZ.question: The ventilation system in a fuel tank..

options.text: prevents low pressure or excessive overpressure in the tank.

Ayg0Bnso.question: Fuel stored in aircraft tanks will accumulate moisture. The most practical way to minimize this when a plane is used every day or so is to:

options.text: keep tanks topped off (full) when plane is not in use.
drain tanks at end of each day's flight.
use only high octane gasoline.
keep tank vents plugged and filler cap tight.

47J1Aesx.question: In a fuel system, the oil to fuel heat exchanger allows

options.text: jet engine oil cooling through thermal exchange with fuel flowing from tanks.

fuel cooling so as to prevent vapour creation likely to unprime the nozzles.

3jUtjfkF.question: Refer to the annex. Given the system in the annex, the main purpose of the DC fuel pump in the left main tank is to:

options.text: supply fuel to the APU.
supply fuel to both engines in case of total loss of AC power.
enable cross-feeding the right engine from the left main tank.
enable transfer of fuel from the main to the centre tank.

1HQ6DPHi.question: A volumetric top off valve on small aircraft typically works on the principle of

options.text: float switches.
capacitive sensing systems.
pressure sensors.
flow rate sensors.

on all transport category aircraft with more than 150 seats.
on aircraft with a Maximum Take-off Weight (MTOW) higher than 5.7 tons.
on all transport category aircraft.

FlXJa1bz.question:
Refer to figure. 
 Which of these statements about the fuel system in the annex are correct or incorrect?
1. If the AC fuel pumps are not running in the system configuration shown in the annex, it is still possible to feed both engines from the main tanks. 
 2. If the APU isolation valve opens, the APU fuel shut off valve is closed and there is no AC power, the DC fuel pump can supply fuel to the engines.

options.text: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.

options.text: To prevent the fuel from forming any ice within
To kill any bacteria
To make the fuel more stable

Given the following parameters, in a capacitance fuel gauge, the correct formula is:
C = capacitance
a = area of plates
d = distance between plates
e = dielectric permittivity

options.text: C = e × a ÷ d
C = a × d ÷ e
C = e × d × a
C = e × d ÷ a

yFYYTMie.question: The functions of an LP booster pump in a gas turbine fuel system are to..

hUim3kDB.question: The refuelling of a large transport jet aircraft is typically performed:

by means of the aircraft suction pumps through a unique point (an underwing refuelling centre).

decrease in combustion chamber temperature and higher thermal efficiency.

options.text: integral fuel tanks.

Item 7

IPFL9pWI.question: On most transport aeroplanes, the low pressure pumps of the fuel system are

options.text: electrically driven centrifugal pumps.
electro-mechanical swash plate pumps, with self-regulated pressure.
hydraulically driven centrifugal pumps.
mechanically driven by the engine`s accessory gearbox.

mbKhmlEs.question: The ventilation system in a fuel tank:

options.text: prevents low pressure or excessive overpressure in the tank.
prevents fuel freezing during flight in icing conditions
prevents vapour locking in the fuel lines.
can be used to drain the tanks, for daily checks.

Ri8ELYvt.question: Fuel tank air pressure is maintained at ambient by:

options.text: the fuel vent system.
the fuel top off unit.
the fuel tank drains.
the fuel dump system.

0SgZrCyC.question: Select the correct order of these fuels based on their freezing points, from coldest to warmest: Jet A-1, Jet A, Jet B.

options.text: Jet B, Jet A-1, Jet A.
Jet B, Jet A, Jet A-1.
Jet A, Jet A-1, Jet B.
They all freeze at the same temperature.

R0S6Tgvg.question: When would the Fuel Low Level warning activate?

options.text: When the fuel is low in any tank that is not expected to empty during flight
When the fuel pump outlet pressure is low
When the fuel is low in a feeder tank
When the fuel is low in all of the tanks

V9rOikbC.question: The most appropriate statement concerning multi-engine jet aeroplane fuel systems, is

options.text: The fuel system may have provisions for heating the fuel before it enters the fuel filter.
Fuel pumps have no provisions for by-pass of fuel.
A mechanically operated and activated fuel valve is called a solenoid valve.
There are no provisions for cross-feed, because each engine has its own tank(s).

0Zeq7Bc4.question: Fuel tanks are fitted with baffles to..

options.text: damp spanwise fuel motion in the tanks.
prevent spanwise fuel motion during constant sideslip.
assist in cooling the fuel.
remove air bubbles from the fuel.

zJgGGyZu.question: The function of a feed box in the fuel tank is to:

options.text: increase the fuel level at the boost pump location and prevent cavitation.
ventilate the tank during refuelling under high pressure.
trap fuel deposits / sediments or sludge in the lower part of the tank.
distribute the fuel to the various tanks during refuelling.

dDhDvQ5S.question: The correct order of decreasing freezing points of the three mentioned fuels is:

options.text: Jet A, Jet A-1, Jet B.
Jet A-1 Jet A, Jet B.
Jet B, Jet A, Jet A-1.
Jet B, Jet A-1, Jet A.

EGMDJBnN.question:
Which statement is correct?
	
1) The freezing point for Jet A is at a lower temperature than that for Jet B.
	
2) The flash point for Jet A is at a lower temperature than that for Jet B.

options.text: 1) is incorrect, 2) is incorrect.
1) is correct, 2) is correct.
1) is correct, 2) is incorrect.
1) is incorrect, 2) is correct.

HYEFYlLQ.question: Using drip sticks, the quantity of fuel is determined by measurements

options.text: Drip sticks & data tables in the aircraft documentation
Dripsticks & current OAT
From the dripsticks and the fuel’s specific gravity
Directly from the drip sticks only

xqSZ7odA.question: On a piston engine aircraft, a filter is installed in the fuel system to...

options.text: remove particles and impurities from the fuel that could damage the engine.
store a small amount of fuel under a certain pressure.
extract the water from the fuel.
allow a person to take a sample of the fuel and to empty the fuel tank for maintenance.

Nrm5Ftbe.question:
Refer to figure 021-22.
Which of the following statements are correct or incorrect?
1) The AC pumps failed but the DC pump is serviceable. The engines can be supplied with fuel from both wing tanks by the DC pump.
2) Both engines can be supplied by the DC pump in a situation which is currently depicted by the diagram.

options.text: 1) incorrect; 2) incorrect
1) correct; 2) incorrect
1) incorrect; 2) correct
1) correct; 2) correct
sometimes minimised by the incorporation of tank sump pads.
always the same quantity irrespective of aircraft attitude or flight conditions.
the amount of fuel not available for use but included on the fuel contents gauge.
fuel drained from the aircraft due to water contamination.

8iXNjOlH.question: The capacitance type fuel gauging system indicates the fuel quantity by measuring the:

options.text: dielectric change between fuel and air.
density variation of the fuel.
resistivity variation of the fuel.
electrical resistance change.

mXoEZ6ht.question: Failure of a capacitive fuel indication system will be indicated by:

options.text: a full deflection of the gauge to empty.
a deflection of the gauge to full.
no change in contents indication.
a yellow flag on the gauge.

A8hWKNp4.question: Refer to the Annex.  Given the system in the Annex, which of these statements about this fuel system is correct?

options.text: It is impossible to transfer fuel from the centre tank to the wing tanks.
Fuel transfer is only possible from the centre tank to the left main tank.
Fuel transfer is only possible from the centre tank to the right main tank.
Fuel transfer is possible from the centre tank to both main tanks.

2s7uUDPr.question: The SI unit of measurement for density is:

options.text: kg/m^3^
psi
bar
kg/cm^2^

kFwsNuxk.question: The SI unit of measurement for density is:

options.text: kg/m^3^
psi.
kg/cm^2^
bar.
